caption: THE BEST MUSEUM I've visited. The museum feels like you're in a zoo where time standstill. The whole place is so beautiful and elegant, every animal is so subtly placed in the museum, it's just fascinating. You can actually open certain drawers to look into the artifacts. And above all of that the staff is so good (very gentle) at this museum, I mean if by mistake you miss some part of the museum they'll help you see it and make sure you see all the good things in there.

Completely out of the mainstream mindset : dead animals, guns and paintings of hunters and dead animals. I let you imagine how weird it can look at first in todayâ€™s world. Yet it is a brilliant â€˜must seeâ€™ place in Paris. Always good surprises to discover. Mix of tradition and fun cutting edge modern arts. I love it (much better than the neighbouring Picasso museum)

Itâ€™s quirky, but if youâ€™re fine with taxidermy, youâ€™ll appreciate how this museum mixes modern art with the stuffed animals. Tickets are just over 10 Euros and it took us an hour to go through, enjoying every room. The signs are in French.

A museum that glorifies the cruel act of enslaving and killing animals by humans to fulfill their selfish desires. It's a matter of time that museums like this will be cancelled. I got in for free on the first Sunday of the month.

To be honest, I don't recommend it. Charging â‚¬13 for such an exposition is too much. There are more artworks than nature here. I'm also annoyed by the guards who follow your every move, there are more of them than exhibitsðŸ˜‚

Taxidermy, black feathered book cave and guns!  Not exactly my jam, but holy cow it totally was!  Not only is it in the heart of the Marias, but it is in the MOST gorgeous mansion, with a gorgeous museum gift shop.  Who knew?!  The current exhibition by Tamara Kistianovsky of cloth sculptures inspired by nature is exquisite! It is so well curated and placed that you feel like you walked into an alternate world where elegance meets whimsy!  Go for a coffee to Sevenly Heaven across the street and luxuriate

A truly amazing museum/gallery, not at all what we expected. There is some very innovative displays and it's quite a fascinating and unique collection, and of course you get to stand next to a massive polar bear. Well worth a few hours, and I doubt if it's ever crowded! Great bookshop too.

A very strange museum which isnâ€™t for the faint hearted. A mix of old and new, taxidermy animals and contemporary art related to nature. I enjoyed it but didnâ€™t feel great about the whole theme. Most of the museum is accessible but there is a small area at the end that is accessed with stairs. Has a gift shop. Free first Sunday of the month, I went on this day and didnâ€™t have to queue.

Such an interesting little museum! The curation is an art piece in itself, there is no place like it in Paris. The staff is also wonderful, if you see anyone who works there looking bored in the galleries, ask them a question! Theyâ€™ll give you some great fun facts.  Save yourself some time at the end for the gift shop, they have some very nice unique items.  The galleries are a little cramped and the taxidermies are displayed out in the open with no alarms, so I would advise against bringing any active children that might want to touch things.

A wonderful surprise about this museum. I was skeptical beforehand but as soon as I entered I understood how wrong I was. Here each detail count, everything is beautiful and interesting. It can please both adults and children. It shows history but also art and tradition. There is so much to look at  and the personnel is really kind. In addition, all the explanation are available also in english. I recommend !!

I have been wanting to visit for years and finally got my chance. Very interesting place, combines our sordid past of killing exotic animals with some more modern messages. As an artist who paints animals, it was a wonderful experience. Lovely, friendly and helpful staff! ðŸ˜Š

What a really cool museum to visit, amazing collection of taxidermy and really informative. Much bigger than expected seeing it from the entrance and lots of interesting things to look at and read. Various languages on the info plaques as well. Would go back again and recommend to anyone interested in hunting\taxidermy
This is a great place to stop. Hundreds of firearms on display and in drawers you can open. The trophy room was incredible. I walked slowly and appreciated everything. I was done in 2 hours.

This place was amazing. They had an awesome collection of animals, random items, and every hunting weapon imaginable. It felt like I was in a Wes Anderson film. No wait at all, even on the weekend, and a super reasonable price. This place is worth the visit!!

Câ€™est bizarre! An eclectic mix of taxidermy, modern and classic artwork.  The curators of the exhibits must have had a good time putting this together and itâ€™s (mostly) an entertaining walk through them. I didnâ€™t see a jackalope on exhibit but it would not have surprised me. If you like whimsy and donâ€™t mind stuffed animals, this is your museum.

Delightful museum that I would have never visited had my friend not suggested it because they enjoyed it so much. Itâ€™s laid out beautifully, has interesting things to read (lots in English), and the staff are so kind. They take the time to show you little things you should take notice of in every room you go.

A Captivating Journey into Hunting and Nature  If you're looking for a unique and unforgettable experience in Paris, the Museum of Hunting and Nature is a must-visit destination. From the moment you step inside, you'll be transported to a different time and place, filled with fascinating exhibits that celebrate the history of hunting and the natural world.  The ambiance of the museum is simply fantastic. The medium-sized facilities are comfortable and well-designed, with plenty of natural light and an immersive atmosphere that encourages exploration and discovery. The service is top-notch, with friendly and knowledgeable staff members always on hand to answer questions and offer guidance.  One of the highlights of the museum is the exceptional quality of the taxidermy on display. The animals are incredibly lifelike, with meticulous attention to detail that really brings them to life. You'll feel like you're standing right next to a wild boar or a majestic stag, marveling at their beauty and grace.  Another aspect that sets this museum apart is its focus on the cultural and historical significance of hunting. Through a series of interactive exhibits and multimedia displays, visitors are able to learn about the evolution of hunting practices and the role they've played in shaping human history.  As for improvements, it would be great to see more interactive exhibits and activities for children. While the museum is certainly engaging for all ages, a few more hands-on experiences could really enhance the overall experience.  In summary, I would highly recommend the Museum of Hunting and Nature to anyone looking for a truly unique and captivating experience in Paris. The ambiance, service, and quality of the products and services offered are all top-notch. I left with a deep appreciation for the beauty and complexity of the natural world, and I can't wait to come back and explore the museum again in the future.

Very nice discovery, the museum is nicely done. Thatâ€™s a mix of historical and modern art objects, each room has its own mood and decor. I would definitely recommend to visit this museum, quite a fascinating place.

One of the weirdest museums I have been to. Not like any museum in Paris. This place was so much more then I expected it to be.  Very interesting, something unique.  The Museum of Hunting and Nature is located in the mansions of GuÃ©nÃ©gaud (17th century) and Mongelas (18th century),is in the heart of the historic Marais district.  It is in this prestigious setting that the visitor (amateur or curious) discovers paintings (Desportes, Chardin, Oudry, Vernet), hunting weapons, naturalized animals from Africa, America and Asia as well as many objects of art.  Exhibits focus on the relationships between humans and the natural environment through the traditions and practices of hunting. Very interesting place and worth the visit. Part of the â€˜freeâ€™ first Sunday of the month museums.
Such a compelling combination of history, science, and modern art. It was also nearly empty on a Saturday in Paris. Highly recommend for those looking for something off the beaten path.

Amazing museum just in the center of Marais neighborhood. It exhibits a wide variety of animals and as well chase guns. It is rather a small museum compared to other museums located in Paris. Would highly recommend if you're interested in wild animal life.
Quirky, funky and fascinating. It's not just dusty taxidermy. New and old art and items mingle effortlessly within every room. Talk to the employees - they might share 'hidden secrets'.
Nice museum, especially the stuffed animals are beautiful to admire.

An absolute gem of a museum.   Really interesting to look at and plenty for youngsters too.  The signs are all in French and while my knowledge French is good, my daughter who is still learning was able to get by.

I went to the annual BEAR party with my friend. I would come back to Paris annually, just for this party. Such a FUN quirky space with lots of history, taxidermy and Hunters Cabin, meets English hunting dogs, meets Wednesday Adamâ€™s vibes. It was pure fun!  *sorry about the poor quality of the photos. It was dark!

Loved loved loved this museum. I am not into hunting, especially hunting for trophies, BUT this is the most intimate, and unusual museum and collection I have ever been in. I could have spent the day.

I'm not particularly interested in hunting, but this museum is a hidden gem. Each room is dedicated to a specific animal, as is decorated according to this theme. It's a beautiful building, that makes reference to another time. If you enjoy art, design and animals, I encourage you to visit this lovely place
The ticket is 10â‚¬ for students The museum is pretty big, takes around 40 min for visiting. preserves many specimens and painting Very beautiful just like others museums in Paris

Would've given it a 5* if it were a bit bigger or the price lower, but aside from that it was really cool. They did a nice job of incorporating art installations in the museum, telling nice stories with the small animal exhibits and some cool stories in the hunting rooms. Well worth it!
Amazing place. It was the highlight of my trip to Paris.

I loved the museum and the information was really helpful for understanding the exposition. The only thing I would say is that this information is only in french unlike other museums that translate it to English. In general, excellent service.

Went to see exhibit by Eva Jospin, who makes forests from hand carved pieces of cardboard. The rest of the museum is devoted to hunting. I'm not a fan of taxidermy but it was interesting to see the  paintings and sculptures.

The Museum of Hunting and Nature is a private museum that displays the collections of the FranÃ§ois Sommer Hunting Foundation, opened in 2003. It contains stuffed animals such as bears and elephants. Lots of deer antlers, elk, etc. Old fishing tools and rifles.
Awesome! Our boys (7 and 9) loved it. Some great works of art including a few Barye sculptures. Free if you're an Amis du Louvre member and always free for children.

Not your every day Parisian museum but interesting nonetheless. The museum is small to medium in size with a mix of modern art, taxidermy, guns, & hunting dogs, birds, small feathery & furry creatures. Certainly a little strange. Museum of Hunting and Nature also is a part of some kind of hunting club. It's one of my favorite unusual museums of Paris.
We're are the lovelies of animal auxiliary and nature this is the best place to visit for of all kind of hunting and nature so calm and you are allowed to take how much pictures u want.

A beautiful place , well organized and with a wonderful decoration. Actually you feel like in a little palace when you are inside. I would recommend this place if you wish to visit mainly with your kids.
Very interesting museum on wildlife and hunting. You can easily spend 1 hr here, it would be fun for children especially.
